STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 7, 2019
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
RE: License #: CP810201490
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Dear Mrs. Adorjan:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 11/04/2019.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability Exit Program (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Vivian D. Malleck, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3284
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Washtenaw County DHHS
Facility Address: 22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Facility Telephone #: (734) 481-8364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994

Supervise foster children
Independent living services

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating immunizations
are not being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
Two of six foster care files reviewed have overdue
immunizations (Men B Cat B, Meningococcal conjugate
Varicella and Hib).
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document in the child’s record within 7
calendar days after placement the information specified in
R 400.12417 (1) and all of the following information:
(v) Identifying marks.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not complete identifying
marks in the person demographic section of the placement
outline.
4

R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about sibling
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provided routine and emergency medical
care.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not provide the
placement outline to the foster parent at the time of
placement/replacement.
REPEAT VIOLATION from 11/01/2018 renewal inspection
Corrective action plan approved 11/20/2018
R 400.12507 Medical/Dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400/12413. Medical, dental and mental health care
provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
Three of three independent living files reviewed had overdue
immunizations (Men B Cat B and varicella).
5

R 400.12506 Education/vocational training/employment.
An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living is
employed full time, actively involved in a job training or
continuing education or a combination of employment and
education.
One of three independent living files reviewed had a resident
who was not employed, in job training or attending school.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans are required in R 400.12419 and R 400.12420.
If the youth has biological children, the service plan must
address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth’s biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
One of five independent living service plans reviewed did not
have a modified initial service plan for the resident’s adjustment
to his new living arrangement.
1.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is
in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
 ISEP 6.30 Supervision oversight.
Supervisor and case worker must meet prior to signing each service plan.
Two of fifteen foster care service plans reviewed did not have a meeting between
the supervisor and case worker prior to the signing of the service plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION from 11/01/2018 renewal inspection
Corrective action plan approved 11/20/2018
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
 DHHS Policy FOM 722.03 Change of placement.
DHHS 69 Action Summary is required for a placement change.
One of three foster care files reviewed with a placement change did not have the
required DHHS Action Summary.
6

 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical passports.
All medical information required by policy and/or law must be provided to the foster
parent. This includes copies of the medical and dental examinations and the
information required in the medical passport. For children first entering foster care
the initial medical passport must be provided to the caregivers within two weeks of
the child’s placement date. The actual date the caregivers receive the medical
passport must be documented in MiSACWIS. All medical information within the
medical passport must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information. Placement Agency Foster Care
(PAFC) providers must provide a copy of the medical passport to MDHHS
monitoring staff as it is updated but no less often than annually. Each foster care
worker who transfers a child’s medical passport to another foster care worker must
sign and date the medical passport verifying the s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy. An updated medical passport
is provided to legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward and the child’s
foster care provider at or prior to each placement.
Five of six foster care files reviewed did not have either a completed, signed and/or
dated medical passport for each quarter reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION from 11/01/2018 renewal inspection
Corrective action plan approved 11/20/2018
 SRM 200 Security Awareness Training.
Authorized personnel with access to criminal history information is to complete
Security Awareness Training within six months of hire and every two years
thereafter.
Four of seven authorized employees did not complete the renewal Security
Awareness Training within two years from the date of their prior Security
Awareness Training.
REPEAT VIOLATION from 11/01/2018 renewal inspection
Corrective action plan approved 11/20/2018
 PA116 722.120 Confidential information is protected in a report.
Two of four special evaluations reviewed did not protect confidential information in
the report by identifying child protective service or maltreatment in care
involvement in the investigation.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Decrease the length of time foster parent(s) and parent(s) sign the parent
agency treatment plan.
7

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 One of four special evaluations reviewed involved a child securing the key to
the locked medication box. The corrective action plan involved moving the
medication to a locked box with an electronic key code. This type of
medication box may be more fail proof along with the expectation to change
the code on a determined basis.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There are no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Washtenaw Department of Health and Human Services submitted two acceptable
corrective action plans not related to maltreatment during this licensing period.
 2019C0217055 cited noncompliance with R 400.12303 Policies and
procedures for application submission and records check for an enrolled
foster parent(s). The corrective action plan was approved 10/22/2019 and is
being monitored for compliance. Washtenaw Department of Health and
Human Services licensing supervisors will review applications and record
checks on enrolled prospective foster parents and develop a tracking system
of documents received.
 2018 renewal inspection citations have been corrected except for the repeat
citations stated in this interim inspection report.
Department of Child Welfare Licensing field analyst did not find any safety concerns
or safety alerts in the homes visited for this inspection period.
8

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
11/10/2019
________________________________________
Vivian D. Malleck Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 12, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
